alert_name: URL Filtering - Known Phishing Campaign Site Access
description: Palo Alto Networks firewall detected user aisherlock@agentix.ad.bakerstreetlabs.io accessing known phishing infrastructure at https://ebjv.com.au/filesharer from London office workstation. URL Filtering engine flagged the domain based on threat intelligence feeds identifying it as active credential phishing campaign targeting enterprises with fake file-sharing lures. Domain ebjv.com.au registered 7 days ago via Namecheap with Cloudflare nameservers, typical disposable phishing infrastructure. Site presents fake OneDrive/Dropbox credential prompt, capturing credentials via form POST to /auth/validate before redirecting to legitimate file to reduce suspicion. Firewall initially blocked access with warning, but user clicked 'Proceed Anyway' override, allowing TCP session to complete (47 seconds, 3.2KB uploaded suggesting credential submission). Threat intelligence correlates this domain with corporate credential harvesting campaigns. Subsequent authentication attempts to Office 365 from external IPs within 4 hours indicate successful credential theft and attacker usage.
user_agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) Chrome/131.0.0.0 Safari/537.36
policy_description: Known phishing campaign infrastructure - credential harvesting site masquerading as file-sharing service
policy_recommendation: CRITICAL: Reset password immediately for aisherlock@agentix.ad.bakerstreetlabs.io, enable MFA if not already active, revoke all active sessions for user account, block ebjv.com.au at DNS and firewall levels (add to corporate blocklist), hunt for similar phishing emails organization-wide (search email logs for 'ebjv.com.au' domain), review URL Filtering policy to prevent 'Proceed Anyway' overrides for phishing category, investigate subsequent authentication activity for aisherlock account (look for impossible travel, unusual access patterns), deploy security awareness training on phishing recognition (newly registered domains, fake file-sharing lures, credential prompts), consider implementing FIDO2 hardware keys for high-risk users to prevent credential phishing attacks, enable Palo Alto Networks Advanced URL Filtering with machine learning analysis to detect zero-day phishing sites before threat intelligence updates
